segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dve bhikkhū sampayojesuṃ.
segments.en: Now at that time two mendicants were overly attached,
and one of them transgressed against the other.

segments.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu tassa bhikkhuno santike accayaṃ accayato deseti;
segments.en: The transgressor confessed to the other mendicant,

segments.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

segments.pli: “idha, bhante, dve bhikkhū sampayojesuṃ, tatreko bhikkhu accasarā.
Atha kho so, bhante, bhikkhu tassa bhikkhuno santike accayaṃ accayato deseti, so bhikkhu nappaṭiggaṇhātī”ti.
Yo ca accayaṃ accayato na passati, yo ca accayaṃ desentassa yathādhammaṃ nappaṭiggaṇhāti—
segments.en: One who doesn’t recognize when they’ve made a mistake. And one who doesn’t properly accept the confession of someone who’s made a mistake.
There are two who are astute.

segments.pli: Yo ca accayaṃ accayato passati, yo ca accayaṃ desentassa yathādhammaṃ paṭiggaṇhāti—
segments.en: One who recognizes when they’ve made a mistake. And one who properly accepts the confession of someone who’s made a mistake.
These are the two who are astute.

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo sudhammāyaṃ sabhāyaṃ deve tāvatiṃse anunayamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
segments.en: Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the Thirty-Three, recited this verse:

suttaplex.blurb: When two mendicants have a falling out, the Buddha recalls the wise words of Sakka on not letting anger ruin friendship.
